nodes.bodyText: We should leave a comment along the lines of the ListenableFuture one explaining why this is safe. It is, because SerializingUtils.copy() will throw when trying to copy the non-(Java) Serializable Optional returned.

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -82,6 +82,19 @@ */ boolean stepDown(); + /** + * Attempts to forcefully take over leadership. That is, it is similar to {@link #blockOnBecomingLeader()}, however + * it does not block and also if it discovers that it is not the leader, it doesn't back down but proposes + * leadership anyway. + *

+ * Note: Whilst a positive result means that it succussfully proposed and became the leader, it is still subject to

nodes.bodyText: This doesn't quite agree with the API of hostileTakeover though (I didn't gain leadership forcefully, I just was already the leader). Probably the API should be reworded to something like true iff this node was the leader at some point during the method call (bearing in mind it might already the be the leader, and that a successful proposal + GC could see another node take over before this method returns).
How did we choose p here? paxos or partitioning shorthand, I guess, but seems a bit unclear
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+services:
+  NamespaceLeadershipTakeoverService:
+    name: Namespace Leadership Takeover Service
+    default-auth: header
+    package: com.palantir.atlasdb.timelock.paxos.api
+    base-path: /tl/p

nodes.bodyText: it was paxos,  should I just name it fully since this isn't a heavily hit endpoint?

nodes.bodyText: nit: the idea that we propose null is now baked in to three places in the code (propose, stepdown and here) - maybe we should refactor this slightly?
